meanings.def: used to emphasize something unexpected or surprising
examples: She didn't even call to say she wasn't coming.
He never even opened the letter (= so he certainly didn't read it).
It wouldn't have been possible 30 years ago, maybe even 20.
It was cold there even in summer (= so it must have been very cold in winter).
Even a child can understand it (= so adults certainly can).

meanings.def: used when you are comparing things, to make the comparison stronger
examples: You know even less about it than I do.
She's even more intelligent than her sister.
The Second World War made things even worse.
We face an even greater challenge today.

meanings.def: used to introduce a more exact description of somebody/something
examples: It's an unattractive building, ugly even.
Although/​Even though/​Though everyone played well, we lost the game.
We lost the game although/​even though/​though everyone played well.
Even everyone played well, we lost the game.

meanings.def: just at the same time as somebody does something or as something else happens
examples: Even as he shouted the warning the car skidded.

meanings.def: despite the possibility that; no matter whether
examples: I'll get there, even if I have to walk.

meanings.def: despite the fact that; even though
examples: He is a great leader, even if he has many enemies.

meanings.def: despite what has/had happened
examples: I've shown him the photographs but even now he won't believe me.
Even then she would not admit her mistake.

meanings.def: at this or that exact moment
examples: The troops are even now preparing to march into the city.

meanings.def: despite that
examples: There are a lot of spelling mistakes; even so, it's quite a good essay.

meanings.def: despite the fact that
examples: I like her, even though she can be annoying at times.
Although/​Even though/​Though everyone played well, we lost the game.
We lost the game although/​even though/​though everyone played well.
Even everyone played well, we lost the game.

related: have an even chance (of doing something)

meanings.def: that can be divided exactly by two
examples: 4, 6, 8 and 10 are all even numbers.

meanings.def: equal or the same for each person, team, place, etc.
examples: Our scores are now even.
the even distribution of food
There is a more even division in the contest for the deputy leadership.
The political goal was a more even distribution of wealth.
There was an even split between male and female students.
The agency's 35 000 employees are an even mix of military and civilians.

meanings.def: equally balanced or of an equal standard
examples: an even contest
The two players were pretty even.
Until then the match looked fairly even.

meanings.def: not changing very much in amount, speed, etc.
examples: Children do not learn at an even pace.
Try to keep your baby's room at an even temperature.

meanings.def: smooth, level and flat
examples: You need an even surface to work on.
The floor isn't completely even.

meanings.def: equally spaced and the same size
examples: even features/teeth
Try to keep your stitches absolutely even.

meanings.def: calm; not changing or becoming upset
examples: She has a very even temperament.
He spoke in a steady, even voice.
Nothing disturbed the even tenor of our life.

meanings.def: to no longer owe somebody money or a favour
examples: If I pay for the meals then we’re even.

meanings.def: to cause somebody the same amount of trouble or harm as they have caused you
examples: I'll get even with you for this, just you wait.

meanings.def: to complete a piece of business, etc. without either losing money or making a profit
examples: The company just about broke even last year.

meanings.def: to be equally likely to do or not do something
examples: She has more than an even chance of winning tomorrow.
There’s an even chance that the jury will find him guilty.

meanings.def: no particular person, team, etc. is doing better than the others in a competition, an argument, etc.
living, working or happening in a calm way, with no sudden changes, especially after a difficult time
examples: Business is now back on an even keel after the strike.
Setting her life back on an even keel after their break-up had been incredibly difficult.
